newsitem.title: UK: Softs Outlook -Sugar to expire, cocoa seen nervous.
newsitem.headline: Softs Outlook -Sugar to expire, cocoa seen nervous.

text.p: LIFFE white sugar futures' May expiration on Tuesday will take the spotlight while cocoa futures try to overcome nervousness from last week's rollercoaster activity.
Coffee futures were seen easing amid roasters' absence as they inventory stocks before the March-end financial period.
Slack EU sugar demand was seen limiting the physical delivery and chances of a short squeeze in London, traders said.
White sugar's expiration is expected to result in a physical delivery of about two cargoes of European Union (EU) origin.

"I think the whites are going through a bit of (a) slump...at the moment, as you're not really shifting sugar, I think people are only taking off the bits and pieces of business that goes on every day," one trader said.
"Nobody is willing to take a big gamble. Everyone is a bit lethargic. I don't think the whites are going to have any real surprises," he said.
Nevertheless, traders will stay watchful of New York because trade houses there are said to be very short nearby months, and uncertainty lingers over availability of origins for May expiry.
After expiration, traders expected usual cross and against actuals activity as May positions are rolled into August, although one major trade house has been buying May outright.
In cocoa, traders said last week's volatile activity had clouded the near-term outlook and widened July's trading band to between 980 and 1,065.
Though cocoa recovered well from last Monday's tumble to about one-month lows made on agressive fund sales, technicians were not yet ruling out another setback.

Lawrence Eagles, commodity analyst with GNI Ltd, said cocoa's upside path would not be cleared until July hurdled its April 2 peak of 1,065 stg. Before that, July would have to break resistance at 1,034 and minor resistances at 1,049 and 1,062.
But he said sustainable gains could be difficult because of signs this year's cocoa deficit would be smaller than forecasts six months ago due to a larger-than-expected Ivorian crop.

And although fund selling dried up late last week, which allowed cocoa to rise to a weekly high on Friday, Eagles speculated that funds remained net long the market and could reemerge to threaten cocoa gains if trade demand did not surface to soak up sales.
Initial July support rests at 985, with critical support at 980. A close below 987 could mean a drop to 940.
Coffee futures were expected to drift lower without any roaster buying activity as roasters returning from Easter continued to inventory for the financial period ending March 31.
Origins are also expected to step up selling into any May advance up to $1,700, making further gains to last month's peak of just above $1,800 seem unlikely in the near-term.
In robusta, producer sales from Vietnam have eased due to the end of the main crop, and the market is now bracing for sales of the main Indonesian harvest.
"Origins have been quiet. However, a scale-up selling is hovering over the market up to $1,700," a trader said.
Indonesia, which is harvesting and shipping its main crop, has been surprisingly quiet, possibly awaiting higher prices.
Immediately, traders said May could drift down to $1,560-$1,540 a tonne this week.
Robusta's fortunes also hinge on New York arabica futures' sharp swings. Traders said a July break below 170 cents a lb could accelerate a fall to the 160- to 165-area.
The possible Colombia truck drivers' strike on April 20 may provide some support, but traders doubt if it would materialise as the government may try to intervene.
--London newsroom +44 171 542 8072
